qas.question: How many zones are the Alps split into?
What is the lowest zone of the Alps called?
Where does the lowest zone of the Alps exist?
Where does the montane zone extend from?
Where does the sub-Alpine zone extend from?

context: The Alps are split into <a0_0>five climatic zones<a0_0/>, each with different vegetation. The climate, plant life and animal life vary among the different sections or zones of the mountains. The lowest zone is the <a1_0>colline zone<a1_0/>, which exists <a2_0>between 500 and 1,000 m<a2_0/> (1,640 and 3,281 ft), depending on the location. The montane zone extends <a3_0>from 800 to 1,700 m<a3_0/> (2,625 to 5,577 ft), followed by the sub-Alpine zone <a4_0>from 1,600 to 2,400 m<a4_0/> (5,249 to 7,874 ft). The Alpine zone, extending from tree line to snow line, is followed by the glacial zone, which covers the glaciated areas of the mountain. Climatic conditions show variances within the same zones; for example, weather conditions at the head of a mountain valley, extending directly from the peaks, are colder and more severe than those at the mouth of a valley which tend to be less severe and receive less snowfall.
